name: Matthew Lumont
history:
Matthew “Stonemason” Lumont

Born to a mid-tier noble house of the Karrakin Trade Baronies, Matthew Lumont was raised in a family defined by contracts, legacy, and quiet violence. Like most Lumont heirs, his childhood revolved around trade arbitration, private security forces, and the unspoken truth that wealth in the Baronies is defended as often as it is negotiated. Education was impeccable, emotions were optional, and failure was remembered for generations.

The Lumonts were not warlords—but they owned the people who were. Matthew learned early that authority didn’t need to shout. It only needed leverage.

Exposure to Union space and ideology during joint security operations cracked that certainty. Union’s emphasis on post-scarcity ethics, shared governance, and transparent command structures clashed violently with Karrakin feudal pragmatism—but it also offered something Matthew had never been promised: merit without inheritance. Against family expectation, he entered Union’s military-adjacent training pipelines, trading heraldry for serial numbers.

Becoming a Lancer finalized the break. Union doesn’t care who your ancestors were, only what you can hold, fix, and protect when everything goes wrong. Matthew earned the callsign “Stonemason” for his methodical combat style and refusal to panic under pressure: slow advances, solid firing lines, and battlefield solutions that stay solved.

To Union, Stonemason is a reliable pilot with a talent for structural warfare and command cohesion.
To the Baronies, he is an asset that walked away and might one day come back wearing different colors.

systems.flavorDescription: The GMS Type-3 Projected Shield traps and denies incoming projectiles by projecting an aggressive, superpositional anti-ballistic barrier.

weapon.flavorDescription:
Much like GMS mechs, GMS weapons are reliable galactic standards, made using interchangeable parts and built to withstand almost any conditions. There are three lines currently in production.
The Type-I (T-1) line is defined by powerful, reliable, and conventional-kinetic ranged and melee weapons, including the GMS assault rifle, heavy machine gun, shotgun, pistol, and various light and heavy blades. Reliable galactic standards, the GMS T-1 line is the most widely used mech-scale line of weaponry across the galaxy. Echoing the Everest’s design notes, T-1 weapons are simply designed, with few (if any) moving parts, intended to be used in or adaptable to any environment.

Much like GMS mechs, GMS weapons are reliable galactic standards, made using interchangeable parts and built to withstand almost any conditions. There are three lines currently in production.
The Type-III (T-3) line is made up of heavy weapons, ordnance, and other exotic, specialized, or massive weapons. A broad classification, the T-3 range includes conventional-kinetic anti-materiel rifles, super-rapid cycling pulse rifles, missile racks, cannons, and drone nexuses – “hive”style launchers that serve as miniature factory, hangar, and deployment systems for portable drones. The classification also includes the fearsome “segment knife”, a system that uses flash-printing to produce disposable edged weapons in a vicinity around the user.

armor.flavorDescription: These hardsuits, common among military units, feature heavier plating than light hardsuits but more mobility than heavy hardsuits. They are powered, augmenting the user’s strength, and typically feature an onboard computer, sensor suite, integrated air, burst EVA system, and waste recycling systems.

weapons.flavorDescription: Medium A/C weapons are typically swords, officer’s sabers, and trench axes.
Medium signature weapons are assault rifles, shotguns, pack-fed lasers, or disruption guns.

gear.flavorDescription: This clear, plastic-like sheet can be placed over the wounds of severely injured pilots. It instantly begins to stabilize them, injecting medicine and deploying nanites to stitch wounds shut.

A strong base-layer suit that recycles water, generates nutrients, and adapts very rapidly to hostile environs, maintaining a stable condition and extending survivability. Flexsuit wearers can go for roughly a week without eating or drink thanks to the ambrosia paste generated by their suit before its systems are depleted; however, they don’t prevent feelings of hunger. Removing the suit for a day or two is enough to replenish its reserves. Flexsuits also maintain a steady temperature within acceptable parameters.

Dataplating is a general term for any comm-linked jewelry, subdermal netting, wearable jaw, brow, or maxillary plates, etc., that allows subvocal communication and persistent heads-up and augmented reality displays without wearing a helm. Dataplates can quickly translate nearly any language, and allow users to communicate with each other all but silently.
